coreConcepts: the marriage of heaven and hell

passages.text: To see a World in a Grain of Sand, And a Heaven in a Wild Flower, Hold Infinity in the palm of your hand, And Eternity in an hour.
passages.source: Auguries of Innocence
passages.context: The infinite in the particular. Every small thing contains the whole, if you know how to see.

passages.text: If the doors of perception were cleansed everything would appear to man as it is, Infinite.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: We don't see infinity because our perception is clouded. Cleanse the doors, see the real.

passages.text: Without contraries there is no progression. Attraction and Repulsion, Reason and Energy, Love and Hate, are necessary to Human existence.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: Opposites aren't problems to solve — they're the engine of growth. No tension, no movement.

passages.text: The road of excess leads to the palace of wisdom.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: You learn limits by transgressing them. Moderation teaches less than extremity.

passages.text: No bird soars too high if he soars with his own wings.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: Your own power can't take you wrong. It's borrowed wings that mislead.

passages.text: The imagination is not a state: it is the human existence itself.
passages.source: Milton
passages.context: Imagination isn't optional or decorative — it's what makes us human. We ARE imagination.

passages.text: A truth that's told with bad intent beats all the lies you can invent.
passages.source: Auguries of Innocence
passages.context: Truth can be weapon. Malicious honesty wounds more than creative lying.

passages.text: The man who never alters his opinion is like standing water, and breeds reptiles of the mind.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: Fixed opinions stagnate. Mental life requires flow. Certainty breeds corruption.

passages.text: I must create a system or be enslaved by another man's. I will not reason and compare: my business is to create.
passages.source: Jerusalem
passages.context: Create your own worldview or live in someone else's. The artist's imperative: make, don't follow.

passages.text: What is now proved was once only imagined.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: All established facts were once wild ideas. Imagination precedes reality.

passages.text: The tigers of wrath are wiser than the horses of instruction.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: Passion teaches more than pedagogy. Wild energy knows things tame learning doesn't.

passages.text: Exuberance is beauty.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: Beauty isn't restraint — it's overflow. The beautiful is the abundant.

passages.text: In the universe, there are things that are known, and things that are unknown, and in between, there are doors.
passages.source: Attributed/Various
passages.context: Between knowledge and mystery are thresholds. Doors can be entered.

passages.text: Those who restrain desire do so because theirs is weak enough to be restrained.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: Moralists who suppress desire have weak desires. Strong desire can't be merely restrained.

passages.text: Energy is eternal delight.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: Energy isn't cost — it's joy. The vital force delights in itself.

passages.text: The fool who persists in his folly will become wise.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: Follow your foolishness far enough and it becomes wisdom. Persist in the absurd.

passages.text: Great things are done when men and mountains meet; this is not done by jostling in the street.
passages.source: Notebooks
passages.context: Greatness requires confrontation with immensity. The crowd produces nothing monumental.

passages.text: He who desires but acts not, breeds pestilence.
passages.source: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
passages.context: Unexpressed desire rots. Wanting without doing corrupts the soul.

passages.text: Every night and every morn, Some to misery are born. Every morn and every night, Some are born to sweet delight.
passages.source: Auguries of Innocence
passages.context: Life distributes joy and suffering unequally. Every moment brings both into the world.

passages.text: The tree which moves some to tears of joy is in the eyes of others only a green thing that stands in the way.
passages.source: Letters
passages.context: The same object is sacred to one and obstacle to another. Perception determines reality.
